review.title: Pitfalls and Best Practices in Algorithm Configuration
review.abstract: Good parameter settings are crucial to achieve high performance in many areas of artificial intelligence (AI), such as satisfiability solving, AI planning, scheduling, and machine learning (in particular deep learning). Automated algorithm configuration methods have recently received much attention in the AI community since they replace tedious, irreproducible and error-prone manual parameter tuning and can lead to new state-of-the-art performance. However, practical applications of algorithm configuration are prone to several (often subtle) pitfalls in the experimental design that can render the procedure ineffective. We identify several common issues and propose best practices for avoiding them, including a tool called GenericWrapper4AC for preventing the many possible problems in measuring the performance of the algorithm being optimized by executing it in a standardized, controlled manner.

metadata.title: Pitfalls and Best Practices in Algorithm Configuration

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In order to obtain the peak performance of an algorithm, it is often necessary to optimize its parameters. Recently, the AI community has developed automated methods for configuring the algorithm (AC), which lead to a new performance (Hutter et al., 2009) to replace tedious, irreproducible and error-prone parameters. Some sample applications for which automatic methods are used include satisfaction solutions (Hutter et al., 2017), maximum satisfaction (Anso Tegui et al., 2016), planning (Chiarandini et al., 2008), mixed integrity programming (Hutter et al.), evolution algorithm algorithm algorithm.

sections.heading: 2 Background: Algorithm Configuration
sections.text: The configuration problem of the algorithm can be briefly described as follows: Given an algorithm A that needs to be optimized (the so-called target algorithm), with parameter configuration space, a set of instances, and a cost metric c: ы × в → R, you will find a configuration. A concrete example of this configuration problem would be to find a parameter that minimizes the cost metrics c across instances. (1) A concrete example of this configuration problem would be to find a parameter that configures a solver A for the propositional satisfaction problem (SAT) (such as glucose (Audemard & Simon, 2009) or lingeling (Biere, 2013) on a set of CNF instances (e.g. hardware or software verification instances) that minimizes the average runtime c. Another example would be to find a hyperparameter that sets an algorithm.

sections.heading: 2.1 Approaches for solving the AC problem
sections.text: There are several quite different configurators to solve this AC problem. ParamILS (Hutter et al., 2009) uses local search in the configuration space and uses a race strategy to decide which of two configurations performs better without running both on all instances. SMAC (Hutter et al., 2011) and its distributed version dSMAC (Hutter et al., 2012) use probabilistic models of algorithm performance, so-called empirical performance models (Hutter et al., 2014), to guide the search for good configurations by extending Bayesian Optimization (Brochu et al., 2010).

sections.heading: 2.2 The Role of the Target Algorithm Wrapper
sections.text: As shown in Figure 1, configurators execute the target algorithm with instances-based configurations and measure the resulting costs. To be universally applicable, configurators must define an interface through which they evaluate the costs for the desired instance and determine the desired costs (e.g. runtime or solution costs). To prevent the algorithm from being optimized, this interface is usually introduced by a twist in the desired instance.

sections.heading: 3 Pitfalls and Best Practices Concerning Algorithm Execu-
sections.text: In this and the next section, we will describe the pitfalls of algorithm configuration and their impact on existing benchmarks in algorithm configuration and configuration. In this context, we will also respond to the way they have occurred in recent years. (...) We will be able to understand and understand the way we move. (...) sections.heading: 4 Pitfalls and Best Practices Concerning Over-Tuning
sections.text: A common problem when using overtuning configurations is the overtuning effect (Birattari, 2004; Hutter et al., 2007). Overtuning is closely related to the concept of overmatch in machine learning and refers to the phenomenon of finding parameter configurations that lead to a result.8 We note that in some modern Linux distributions, / tmp / can be a RAM disk and can therefore use resources allocated to algorithm runs; in general, we recommend choosing a fast temporary directory that is specific to the cluster used. 9This problem is fixed in later versions of UBCSAT.strong for the training task, but is not generalized to test tasks. To protect against overtuning effects, we recommend always evaluating generalization performance (typically using a set of benchmark instances that are coupled with the benchmarks used for training) in the following three.

sections.heading: 4.1 Pitfall 5: Over-tuning to Random Seeds
sections.text: Many algorithms are randomized (e.g., SAT solvers or AI planners), but in many communities, the random seeds of these algorithms are fixed to simulate deterministic behavior and ensure the reproducibility of benchmark results. Effect Ignoring the stochasticity of an algorithm configuration by fixing the random seed can be over-tuning effects to this seed, i.e., finding a configuration that performs well with this fixed random seed but performs poorly when used with other random seed. The extreme case is not to repair the random seed, but to adjust the random seed, which can lead to an even stronger overtuning effect.

sections.heading: 4.3 Pitfall 7: Over-tuning to a Particular Machine Type
sections.text: In the age of cloud computing and mainframes, it is obvious to use these remote resources to configure them. However, these remote machines are not always able to perform well.

sections.heading: 5 Further Recommendations for Effective Configuration
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

Another example would be to find a hyperparameter setting for a machine learning algorithm that minimizes its error c on a given dataset (Snoek et al., 2012; Feurer et al., 2015); in this latter example, error could either be measured via k-fold inner crossvalidation (giving rise to k instances for algorithm configuration), or a single validation set (in which case there is just a single instance for algorithm configuration).

Another example would be to find a hyperparameter setting for a machine learning algorithm that minimizes its error c on a given dataset (Snoek et al., 2012; Feurer et al., 2015); in this latter example, error could either be measured via k-fold inner crossvalidation (giving rise to k instances for algorithm configuration), or a single validation set (in which case there is just a single instance for algorithm configuration).

If the cost metric c is running time, several configurators use an adaptive capping strategy (Hutter et al., 2009) to terminate slow algorithm runs prematurely to save time.

In contrast to SMAC , GGA++ does not require a wrapper; in the experiments by Ansótegui et al. (2015), GGA++ directly sent its KILL signal to the target algorithm and therefore did not suffer from the same problem SMAC suffered from, which confounded the paper’s comparison between GGA++ and SMAC .

For studies comparing configurators, it is also paramount to use tried-and-tested publicly available benchmark scenarios (lowering the riks of typos, etc); our algorithm configuration benchmark library AClib (Hutter et al., 2014) provides a very broad collection of such benchmarks.

We therefore analyzed this benchmark further (Hutter et al., 2017), showing that twice as many SMAC runs with a fivefold larger configuration budget managed to improve training performance slightly.

Unfortunately, this does not hold for all kind of algorithms – for example, the performance of solvers for SAT (Aigner et al., 2013) and mixed integer programming (Lodi & Tramontani, 2014) can depend strongly on the used machine type (including hardware, operating system and installed software libraries)
Geschwender et al. (2014) showed in a preliminary study that it is possible in principle to configure algorithms in the cloud and for the found configurations to perform well on another machine.
Example An example for such machine-dependent algorithms are SAT solvers that are often highly optimized against cache misses (Aigner et al., 2013).

To obtain trivial parallelization of randomized configuration procedures, we recommend to run n independent configuration runs and use the training set to select the best of the n resulting configurations (Hutter et al., 2012).
Using training instances from a range of hardness can also often help yield configurations that generalize (Hoos et al., 2013).

, Hutter et al. (2012)).
With SMAC , we have successfully optimized configuration spaces with hundreds of parameters (Thornton et al., 2013).

For example, the state-of-the-art SAT solver Lingeling (Biere, 2013) has more than 300 parameters and most of them have a value range between 0 and 32bit maxint, but most of these parameters are either not really relevant for optimizing Lingeling ’s running time or the relevant value ranges are much smaller.
Hutter et al. (2011) only used a single core per run of GGA, but still followed the protocol by Ansótegui et al.

(2011) only used a single core per run of GGA, but still followed the protocol by Ansótegui et al. (2009) to race groups of 8 runs in parallel per core; therefore, GGA’s adaptive capping mechanism was the same in that work as in Ansótegui et al.

(2011) only used a single core per run of GGA, but still followed the protocol by Ansótegui et al. (2009) to race groups of 8 runs in parallel per core; therefore, GGA’s adaptive capping mechanism was the same in that work as in Ansótegui et al. (2009).

One solution for this case is to measure elementary operations, such as search steps of a local search algorithm or MEMS (number of memory accesses (Knuth, 2011)); however, it has to be ensured that such proxy metrics correlate well with running time.
The only existing library of such benchmarks we are aware of is the algorithm configuration library AClib (Hutter et al., 2014), which comprises 326 benchmarks in Version 1.

We thank Manuel López-Ibáñez and Kevin Tierney for adapting the interfaces of irace and GGA to work together with GenericWrapper4AC, Yuri Malitsky and Horst Samulowitz for providing the wrappers and benchmarks of Ansótegui et al. (2015), and Kevin Tierney, Manuel López-Ibáñez and Lars Kotthoff for very helpful feedback on the first draft of the paper that led to the inclusion of some further possible issues.

We thank Manuel López-Ibáñez and Kevin Tierney for adapting the interfaces of irace and GGA to work together with GenericWrapper4AC, Yuri Malitsky and Horst Samulowitz for providing the wrappers and benchmarks of Ansótegui et al. (2015), and Kevin Tierney, Manuel López-Ibáñez and Lars Kotthoff for very helpful feedback on the first draft of the paper that led to the inclusion of some further possible issues. Some of the recommendations in Section 5 were inspired by a discussion at a Dagstuhl seminar (see Lindauer and Hutter (2017) for more details) and we are thankful for the valuable contributions of the attendees of that discussion: Aymeric Blot, Wanru Gao, Holger Hoos, Laetitia Jourdan, Lars Kotthoff, Manuel López-Ibáñez, Nysret Musliu, Günter Rudolph, Marc Schoenauer, Thomas Stützle and Joaquin Vanschoren.

metadata.abstractText: Good parameter settings are crucial to achieve high performance in many areas of artificial intelligence (AI), such as satisfiability solving, AI planning, scheduling, and machine learning (in particular deep learning). Automated algorithm configuration methods have recently received much attention in the AI community since they replace tedious, irreproducible and error-prone manual parameter tuning and can lead to new state-of-the-art performance. However, practical applications of algorithm configuration are prone to several (often subtle) pitfalls in the experimental design that can render the procedure ineffective. We identify several common issues and propose best practices for avoiding them, including a tool called GenericWrapper4AC for preventing the many possible problems in measuring the performance of the algorithm being optimized by executing it in a standardized, controlled manner.
metadata.creator: TeX
